column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Deal with Exposed Tree Roots
#Text=As a tree ages , shallow roots can sometimes expand to the point that they become exposed above the surface of the soil .
#Text=Roots can also become exposed due to soil erosion or cramped conditions forcing the roots to the surface .
#Text=If your tree has exposed roots that are causing problems , try covering the roots with mulch or an attractive ground cover .
#Text=As a last resort , consider removing or partially removing a problem root .
#Text=Prevent problems by planting your trees strategically and choosing species that are less prone to surface roots .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Covering Exposed Roots with Mulch
#Text=Select an organic mulch material .
#Text=A layer of mulch around the tree ’s roots can cushion and insulate the roots and minimize soil erosion .
#Text=Pick a material that wo n’t absorb too much moisture from the soil around the base of the tree .
#Text=A few options include :
#Text=Pine straw .
#Text=This material is not absorbent , and will allow moisture to reach your tree ’s roots easily .
#Text=Pine bark nuggets .
#Text=If you choose this material , make sure to remove old nuggets before laying down new ones , or the old mulch may absorb too much moisture from around the tree ’s roots .
#Text=Shredded wood mulch .
#Text=Because this material absorbs moisture easily , avoid putting too much at the base of your tree .
#Text=Use a layer only about 1 inch ( 2.5 cm ) thick .
#Text=Put down a layer of mulch no more than 3-4 inches ( 7.6-10.2 cm ) thick .
#Text=You will need to put down enough mulch to cover the exposed roots , but take care not to put down so much that you smother the roots .
#Text=Use thinner layers when applying more absorbent mulches ( such as shredded wood ) , and take care that the pile does n’t become too thick when you refresh the mulch .
#Text=Make the area of mulch wide enough to cover the exposed roots .
#Text=Your mulched area may need to be up to 2/3rds the diameter of the tree ’s canopy .
#Text=Do n’t worry if the mulch covers up part of the lawn around the tree .
#Text=Allowing your roots to compete with your grass will only lead to further soil erosion .
#Text=Avoid piling mulch against the trunk of the tree .
#Text=If you pile up too much mulch around the base of the tree , it may cause the bark at the bottom of the tree to become diseased .
#Text=Leave a little space between your mulched area and the base of the tree .
#Text=Planting Ground Cover over the Roots
#Text=Break up the top 1 inch ( 2.5 cm ) layer of soil around the roots .
#Text=Use a spading fork to very carefully break up the compacted topsoil between the surface roots .
#Text=Take care not to damage the roots themselves , and go no deeper than 1 inch ( 2.5 cm ) .
#Text=Spread no more than 2 inches ( 5 cm ) of garden soil over the topsoil .
#Text=Add garden soil to your newly broken-up topsoil layer , being very careful not to layer on more than 2 inches ( 5 cm ) of new soil .
#Text=If you add too much new soil , your tree ’s roots will suffocate , and the tree will eventually die .
#Text=While you may need to replenish the new soil each year , do not add more than 2 inches ( 5 cm ) of soil to the base of your tree per year .
#Text=Add a light application of general-purpose granular fertilizer .
#Text=Adding some fertilizer will help keep your tree healthy and prevent the ground cover plants from using up too many valuable nutrients .
#Text=Following the package directions , sprinkle a little 15-5-10 or 13-13-13 NPK fertilizer over the exposed root area .
#Text=Plant a shade-loving ground cover plant around the base of the tree .
#Text=Pick a hearty plant that does n’t need a lot of sunlight or moisture .
#Text=In general , the best times to plant ground cover plants are early spring and late fall .
#Text=A few good options include :
#Text=Wild violets
#Text=Ajuga
#Text=Periwinkle ( vinca )
#Text=Asiatic jasmine
#Text=Monkey grass
#Text=Preventing Root Exposure
#Text=Avoid planting shade trees too close to buildings and paths .
#Text=Surface roots mainly become a problem when they interfere with footpaths , sidewalks , and structures such as house foundations .
#Text=Try to plant shade trees no closer than 6 feet ( 2 meters ) from sidewalks and pavements , and 15 feet ( 5 meters ) from house foundations .
#Text=Plant tree species that are less prone to root exposure .
#Text=Root exposure problems are often associated with fast-growing shade trees , such as Arizona ash , silver maple , poplar , and willow .
#Text=When selecting trees to plant on your property , consider choosing slower-growing species instead .
#Text=A few good options include :
#Text=Linden
#Text=Colorado
#Text=blue spruce
#Text=Sugar maple
#Text=Japanese maple
#Text=Red buckeye
#Text=Take measures to prevent soil erosion on your property .
#Text=Tree roots are often exposed by soil erosion .
#Text=If your property has serious erosion problems , you may need to bring in a landscaping expert to install erosion barriers .
#Text=Other measures you can take include :
#Text=Covering bare patches of soil with mulch or ground cover plants , especially on slopes .
#Text=Not over-watering your plants so that you do not wash away too much soil .
#Text=Using jute netting or coconut fiber mats to keep soil in place until cover plants can become established .
#Text=Putting a layer of mulch around the bases of newly-planted trees to prevent erosion as the tree grows .
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Covering Exposed Roots with Mulch
#Text=Organic mulch , such as pine straw , shredded wood , or pine bark nuggets
#Text=Planting Ground Cover over the Roots
#Text=Spading fork
#Text=Garden soil mix
#Text=General-purpose granular fertilizer ( 15-5-10 or 13-13-13 )
#Text=Shade-loving ground cover plants , such as violets , vinca , or Asiatic jasmine
#Text=Trimming Exposed Roots
#Text=Garden spade
#Text=Root saw ( for larger roots ) or shears or loppers ( for smaller roots )
#Text=Root barrier to prevent regrowth
#Text=Preventing Root Exposure
#Text=Slow-growing shade trees , such as blue spruce , linden , or red buckeye
#Text=Mulch
#Text=Soil-retention materials , such as jute netting or coconut fiber mats
